Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Fate and Transport of Antibiotics and Antibiotic Resistance Genes During Historic Colorado Flood

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1402651
Pruden

Recently it has come to the attention of the scientific community and to the public that pharmaceutical compounds are being found in many natural waters, for example, streams, rivers, lakes and sometimes groundwater. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the World Health Organization, and numerous other global and national agencies have recognized that one potential implication of these findings is that bacterial normally found in natural water may develop resistance to the antibiotics. This may be one of the most critical challenges of this century. Studies have shown that antibiotic resistant bacteria can be selected, maintained, and transported within various environmental compartments, by environmental compartments we mean streams and rivers. This project seeks to explore the impact of the recent flooding in Colorado on what is referred to as mobilization of pharmaceuticals (the partitioning of pharmaceutical compounds from sediments to the flowing water) and to investigate whether or not there is an increase in antibiotic resistance in these organisms associated with these waters. With a database of 10 years in the South Platte River the research team is well positioned to conduct additional sampling. This project will be supporting graduate and undergraduate students from three participating universities and will be used for the students as part of undergraduate independent research or graduate student thesis and dissertations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Antibiotic resistance, which occurs when bacteria are not killed by antibiotic therapies, is a growing global threat to human health. The historic one-in-500 year flooding event that occurred in 2013 across the Colorado Front Range afforded a unique opportunity to understand the role of environmental processes in the spread of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) from urban and agricultural sources through the water environment. ARGs are of interest because they are the segments of DNA that enable bacteria to survive antibiotic therapy.  ARGs can be shared between bacteria and bacteria carrying ARGs can survive and outcompete other bacteria in the presence of antibiotics, metals, or other selectors.  ARGs, antibiotics, and metals can enter watersheds from wastewater treatment plants and agricultural operations. Our team had already been monitoring the Cache La Poudre (Poudre) River for over a decade prior to the flood and therefore we were in a unique position to understand the effect of this historic flood on the spread of antibiotic resistance. The Poudre River has been ideal for understanding the influence of human activities on the spread of antibiotic resistance because it originates in a pristine area of the Rocky Mountains before flowing through defined regions of urban and agricultural land-use.

Here we used a relatively new DNA sequencing technology, shot-gun metagenomics, to examine how the flooding and associated selective agents (i.e., antibiotics and metals) influenced the kinds and levels of ARGs in the river water and sediment. We also used a method called quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) to quantify specific ARGs of interest down to very low levels.  Twenty-three antibiotics were analyzed using liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (LC/MS/MS) and fourteen heavy metals were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP/MS). We compared results from four sampling events after the flood with a sampling event from one year prior.

Through metagenomics, we identified over 500 ARG subtypes across the samples.  Notably, there was a striking shift in the collective types and quantities of ARGs detected (i.e., the "resistome") after the flood at the pristine site, becoming more similar to the site historically most heavily influenced by wastewater treatment plants and animal feeding operations when it was sampled before the flood. Several correlations among ARGs and antibiotics or metals were observed. This could be either because they were spread in the watershed through the same mechanism (e.g., same source and same water flow patterns) or because ARG spread better by gene transfer and bacterial growth in their presence. We noted that the sul1 ARG was especially strongly correlated with several sulfonamide and macrolide antibiotics. The sul1 gene has been noted to correlate well with human inputs to the watershed in our past work and is of interest because it is associated with class 1 integrons, which facilitate sharing of ARGs among bacteria. We performed network analysis of de novo assembled DNA sequencing reads into 52,556 scaffolds, which allowed us to identify several ARGs likely located on mobile genetic elements, such as integrons.  Sometimes up to 11 ARGs were found on the same plasmid, indicating that a factor that selects for one of these ARGs could contribute to the spreading of the other 10 ARGs.
